irish.text: May good luck be your friend in whatever you do and may trouble be always a stranger to you.
Even a good horse can't keep running.
A new broom sweeps clean, but the old brush knows the corners.
Praise the ripe field not the green corn.
A friend's eye is a good mirror.
Leave the bad tale where you found it.
God never shuts one door but he opens another.
God made time, but man made haste.
God likes help when helping people.
Anything will fit a naked man.
A short visit is best and that not too often.
A glutton lives to eat; a wise man eats to live.

A good beginning is half the work.
A good denial, the best point in law.
A good farmer is know by his crops.
A good heart never went to hell.

'i see,' said the blind man when he was directed on his way.
'my belly thinks my throat is cut,' as the hungry man said.

'what a dust we kick up,' as the fly said to the cart wheel.

irish.text: Always remember that hindsight is the best insight to foresight.

irish.description: The Greek philosopher Plato once said that action is character. People are not defined by what they say because a lot of talk does not mean anything. People are judged by the things they do. Your actions are more important than what you say.

Distant hills look green.
Do not bless the fish till it gets to the land.
Do not build the sty before the litter comes.
Don’t build the sty before (you get) the pigs. (Lest you might never get them.)
Do not entertain extravagant hopes. – Do not expect too much.
Do not let your eye go beyond what is your own property; do not covet what is not yours..
Do not mistake a goats beard for a fine stallion’s tail.
Do not resent growing old. Many are denied the privilege.
Do not take the thatch from your own roof to buy slates for another man’s house.
Don’t be breaking your shin on a stool that’s not in your way – don’t make trouble for yourself unnecessarily.
Don’t be breaking your shin on a stool that’s not in your way.
Don’t tell your secret even to a fence.
Don’t be ever in court or a castle without a woman to make your excuse.
Don’t be hard and don’t be soft and don’t desert your friend for your own share.
Don’t be too friendly with the clergy and don’t fall out with them.
Don’t begin to reap your neighbour’s corn till he asks you.
Don’t bid the devil good day till you meet him.
Don’t bless the fish till it gets to the land.
Don’t blow on dead embers.
irish.category: irish proverb(i.e. do not attempt a hopeless or impossible task.

irish.text: Don’t bother the beggar’s son and the beggar’s son won’t bother you.
Don’t break your laidhricín on a stool that isn’t in your way.
Don’t break your shin on a stool that isn’t in your way.
irish.category: irish proverb(don’t go out of your way to get into trouble.)

irish.text: Don’t break your shin on a stool that is not in your way.
Don’t bring all your eggs to one market.
Don’t build the sty until the litter comes.
Don’t count your chickens before they are hatched.
irish.description: This proverb warns against being too eager. Just because you have five eggs, does not mean you will have five chickens. It is not a good idea to make plans based on expectations (what you think will happen). Wait for all things to come true before building up your dreams. Or worse, your promises. Things may not happen like you thought they would and that could get you in trouble.

irish.text: Don’t crow till you’re out of the woods.
Don’t cut your cactus in a neighbor’s garden.
Don’t demand your rights until you have the power.
Don’t expect a cherry tree from an acorn.
Don’t expect to be long in this world, but try to be good while you are in it, for death is certain.
Don’t give cherries to a pig; don’t give advice to a fool.
Don’t give judgment on the first story till you hear the other side.
Don’t go early or late to the well.
Don’t go putting wool on a sheep’s back.
Don’t go to law with the devil in the court of hell.
Don’t let your tongue cut your throat.
Don’t lift me till I fall. (Wait till I go wrong before you begin to correct me.)
Don’t make little of your dish for it may be an ignorant fellow who judges it.
Don’t make little of your dish, for it may be an ignorant person who judges it.
Don’t marry a wife on account of cattle.
Don’t meddle with a briar and the briar will not meddle with you.
Don’t mention him and a decent man in the one day.
Don’t neglect your betterment: repentance is not (yet) late.
Don’t outstay your welcome like a neighbor’s goat.
Don’t postpone the good deed.
Don’t postpone your betterment.
Don’t praise or dispraise yourself.
Don’t put ease before exertion.
Don’t put in your spoon where there is no porridge.
Don’t rest your eyes beyond what is your own.
Don’t say everything you want to say lest you hear something you would not like to hear.
Don’t see all you see and don’t hear all you hear.
Don’t show your teeth where you cannot bite.
Don’t take a slate off your own house to put on your neighbor’s.
Don’t talk about a rope in the house of someone whose father was hung.
Don’t tell secrets to the children of your relatives.
Don’t tell your complaint to one who has no pity.
Don’t throw out even dirty water until you have the clean water in.
Don’t throw out the dirty water till you bring in the clean.
Don’t throw out the dirty water until you have the clean water in.
Drink is the curse of the land. It makes you fight with your neighbour. It makes you shoot at your landlord – and it makes you miss him.
Drink is the curse of the land. It makes you fight with your neighbor. It makes you shoot at your landlord, and it makes you miss him.
Drunkenness and anger, ’tis said tell the truth.
Early sow, early mow.
Eaten bread is forgotten.
Eight hours for the man, and nine for the woman (i.e., sleep).
Enough and no waste is as good as a feast.
Enough is a feast.
Enquiry is the beginning of knowledge.
Knowledge is bettered by [sound] enquiry [and inspection].
Even a fool has luck.
Even a good horse can’t keep running.
Even a trifling thing pleases a poor man.
Even gold can be bought too dearly.
Even if love is not around the corner there’s hardly a fight or you would have heard it.
Even truth may be bitter.
Every dog is brave on his own doorstep.
Every finger has not the same length, nor every son the same disposition.
Every flatterer is not a friend.
Every man has his own little bad luck awaiting on him.
Every man is sociable until a cow invades his garden.
‘Every man to his fancy, and me to my own fancy,’ said the old woman when she kissed her cow.
Every terrier is bold in the doorway of its own house.
Every tide has an ebb save the tide of graces.
Everyone praises his own land.
Everything dear is a woman’s fancy.
Everything is (sooner or later) consumed.
Everything is revealed by time.
Face the sun, but turn your back to the storm.
Fame lasts longer than riches.
Fencing a field after the plunder has been committed.
irish.category: irish proverb(i.e. "locking the stable-door when the steed has been stolen.")

irish.text: Fight manly if you must fight, but avoid it if you can.
Fine feathers make fine birds.
irish.category: irish proverbcompare: clothes make the lad, but food makes the fine lad (scottish).

irish.text: Firelight will not let you read fine stories, but it’s warm and won’t let you see the dust on the floor.
Firelight will not let you read fine stories, but it’s warm, and you won’t see the dust on the floor.
Firelight will not let you to read fine stories but it will warm you and you won’t see the dust on the floor.
Food is a good workhorse.
Foolish love is blind.
For a young man contemplating marriage: That you might have nicer legs than your own under your table before the new spuds are up.
For his learning and manners you may praise a man.
For what cannot be cured patience is the best remedy.
irish.category: irish proverbenglish: "what cannot be cured must be endured."

irish.text: Foresight [sometimes: patience] conquers destiny.
Forgetting a debt doesn’t mean it’s paid.
Four things which an Irishman ought not to trust: A cow’s horn, a horse’s hoof, a dog’s snarl, and an Englishman’s laugh.
From education comes conduct.
From the day you marry your heart will be in your mouth and your hand in your pocket.
Generosity which is dilatory is worth going to meet.
Gentleness is better than violent anger.
Get down on your knees and thank God you’re still on your feet.
Giving a warning to one who is doomed (i.e. a futile task.)
Go to a man who is in difficulty and you’ll get a bargain.
God is good, but never dance in a small boat.
God’s help is nearer than the door.
God’s mill grinds very finely.
Gold is light with a fool.
Good care takes the head off (i.e., destroys) the evil or accident.
Good humor comes from the kitchen.
Good sense is no less important than food.
Goods are consumed by being used in small quantities.
Greatness knows modesty.
Half is better than a complete refusal.
Half the work is a good beginning.
Handfuls make up a load.
Handle the pudding while it’s hot.
Harvest is green.
Have a mouth of ivy and a heart of holly.
He couldn’t drag a herring off the coals.
He is a good horse that never stumbles.
He is a sorry wretch who fails to keep his bonds.
He is a wise man who can tell what is going to happen tomorrow.
He is a wise man who takes care of himself.
He is scant of news that speaks ill of his mother.
He may die of wind but he’ll never die of wisdom.
He who comes with a story to you brings two away from you
He who doesn’t look ahead remains behind..
He who has water and peat on his own farm has the world his own way.
He who is bad at giving a lodging is good at show the road.
He who is beaten in the head is timid.
irish.category: irish proverb("beaten in the head" means mentally oppressed or subdued.)

irish.text: He who is lazy in spring is envious at harvest-time.
He who lies down with dogs shall rise with fleas.
He who loses money, loses much; he who loses a friend, loses more; he who loses faith, loses all.
Health and long life to you.Land without rent to you.A child every year to you.And if you can’t go to heaven,May you at least die in Ireland.
He’d offer you an egg if you promised not to break the shell.
Here’s health to your enemies’ enemies!
Here’s to eyes in your heads and none in your spuds.
Here’s to Hell! May the stay there be as fun as the way there!
Here’s to me, and here’s to you. And here’s to love and laughter. I’ll be true as long as you. And not one moment after.
Here’s to a long life and a merry one. A quick death and an easy one. A pretty girl and an honest one. A cold pint and another one!
Here’s to women’s kisses, and to whiskey, amber clear. Not as sweet as a woman’s kiss, but a darn sight more sincere!
He’s more to be pitied than laughed at.
Hold on to the bone and the dog will follow you.
Honey is sweet, but don’t lick it off a briar.
Hoping to recoup ruins the gambler.
how ever long the day the evening will come.
How small a thing outlives a man. Cf. the Scottish: It is a small thing that does not outlive a man.
However long the day, the evening will come.
Humor to a man is like a feather pillow.It is filled with what is easy to getbut gives great comfort.
Humour, to a man, is like a feather pillow. It is filled with what is easy to get but gives great comfort.
I complained that I had no shoes until I met a man who had no feet.
I don’t like a man who is bribed. In Gaelic: Níhail liom fear breibe.
‘i see,’ said the blind man when he was directed on his way.
Idle dogs worry sheep.
Idleness is a fool’s desire.
If a person wants to catch a trout he must do more than merely listen to the flood.
If Candlemas is wet or foul, half the winter has gone at Yule. If Candlemas is fine and fair, half the winter is to come and more.
If he went to a wedding, he’d wait for the christening. (Said of a man who overstays his welcome)
If he’s not fishing, he’s mending his nets (To be said of someone who is very organized) .
If it’s drowning you’re after, don’t torment yourself with shallow water.
If it’s a secret, it’s binding.
If it’s got badly, it’ll go badly.
If that man went to a wedding, he’d stay for the christening (To be said of someone who outstays their welcome).
If the cap doesn’t fit, don’t wear it.
If the potato misses, Ireland’s beaten.
If you are enough lucky to be Irish, you are lucky enough!
If you are inquisitive be knowledgeable.
If you are wise, take advice.
If you buy what you don’t need you might have to sell what you do.
If you buy what you don’t need, you might have to sell what you do.
If you cannot bite, never show your teeth.
If you catch a pig, catch it by the leg.
If you dig a grave for others you may fall into it yourself.
If you do not sow in the spring, you will not reap in the autumn.
If you don’t know the way, walk slowly.
If you don’t want flour on your shoes, don’t go into the mill.
If you don’t want flour, do not get into the mill.
If you give the loan of your breeches, don’t cut off the buttons.
If you give the loan of your britches, don’t cut off the buttons.
If you have a roving eye, it’s no use having the other one fixed on Heaven.
If you have to swallow a frog, try not to think about it. If you have to swallow two frogs, don’t swallow the smaller one first.
If you keep bad company, you are sure to suffer.
If you lend your coat, don’t cut off the buttons.
If you lie down with dogs you’ll rise with fleas.
If you lie down with dogs, you’ll rise with fleas.
If you meet a red-haired woman, you’ll meet a crowd.
If you must be in rags, let your rags be tidy.
If you think little of the meadow don’t buy the grass.
If you want praise, die. If you want blame, marry.
If you want to know what God thinks of money, just look at who He gives it to!
If you’re enough lucky to be Irish… You’re lucky enough!
If your messenger is slow, go to meet him.
I’ll go there tonight for evening is speedier than morning.
In every land, hardness is in the north of it, softness in the south, industry in the east, and fire and inspiration in the west.
In the beginning of the disease the cure is best.
In the land of the blind, the one-eyed man is king.
In winter the milk goes to the cow’s horns.
Intelligence is better than strength.
It is "time enough" [that] lost the race.
It is a bad hen can’t scrape for herself.
It is a good horse that you cannot make stumble.
irish.category: irish proverb(he is a great person who never makes a mistake.)

irish.text: It is a good story that fills the stomach.
It is a good thing to be economical in order to guard against want; but I do not recommend you to be mean or niggardly.
It is a lonely washing that has no man’s shirt in it.
It is a lonesome washing without a man’s shirt in it.
It is a long road that has no turn in it.
It is a wedge from itself that splits the oak.
irish.category: irish proverb(a small group of seceders from a party can do the latter more harm than all the forces of the enemy.)

irish.text: It is afterwards events are understood.
It is bad not to take advice, but it is far worse to take every advice.
It is better to be a coward for a minute than dead the rest of your life.
It is better to be alone than in bad company.
It is better to be engaged in putting knots on a straw than to be completely idle.
It is better to be lucky than an early riser.
It is better to be lucky than rich.
It is better to be lucky than to be an early riser.
It is better to be lucky than wise.
It is better to spend money like there’s no tomorrow than to spend tonight like there’s no money!
It is easier to fall than to rise.
It is easier to get counsel than help.
It is easy to comb a little horse.
irish.category: irish proverb(small enterprises are easily accomplished.)

irish.text: It is easy to drive with your own whip and another’s horse.
It is easy to knead when meal is at hand.
irish.category: irish proverb(i.e. work is easily done when one has all the appliances for doing it.)

irish.text: It is easy to put up with the misfortunes of others.
It is foolish not to enjoy, with due moderation, the good things you have.
It is good news to have no bad news.
It is hard to drive a hare out of a bush in which he is not.
It is hard to take stockings off a bare foot.
It is hard to take wool off a goat.
irish.category: irish proverb[note: it would depend on which sort of goat it is. cashmere goats and angora goats have wool of great value, and angora goats are calm and trusty too.]

irish.text: It is not a feast till the roast, and there are no galling trials till marriage.
It is not every day daddy kills a deer (i.e., ‘It is rarely we have an occasion like this.’)
It is not he who eats most that lives longest.
It is not the time to go for the doctor when the patient is dead.
It is not usual to have smoke without fire; nor fire without people.
It is often that a person’s mouth broke his nose.
It is one’s self knows best where the boot is pressing on the foot.
It is right to put something by for the sore foot (i.e., misfortune).
It is the (early) bird of the morning that gets the worm.
It is the multitude of hands that makes the work light.
It is the smooth water that runs deepest.
It is then that friends are known, when one is in danger.
It takes time to build castles.
It’s a lonely washing that has no man’s shirt in it.
It’s difficult to choose between two blind goats.
It’s easy to halve the potato where there’s love.
It’s for her own good that the cat purrs.
It’s a bad hen that won’t scratch herself.
It’s a bad hound that’s not worth the whistling.
It’s a small thing that outlives a man.
It’s as hard to see a woman crying as it is to see a barefooted duck.
It’s bad manners to talk about ropes in the house of a man whose father was hanged.
It’s better than it’s want.
It’s better than the loan you couldn’t get.
It’s better to be sorry and stay, than to be sorry and go away.
It’s better to return from the centre of the ford than drown in the flood.
It’s difficult to trust a woman.
It’s easy to knead when meal is at hand.
It’s gradually that castles are built.
It’s hard to kill a bad thing.
It’s hard to make a choice between two blind dogs.
It’s hard to take britches off bare hips.
It’s hard to teach an old dog to dance.
It’s just a wisp in place of a brush.
It’s natural for ducks to go barefoot.
It’s no delay to stop to edge the tool.
It’s no secret that’s know to three.
It’s no use boiling your cabbage twice.
It’s no use carrying an umbrella if your shoes are leaking.
Its no use going to the goat’s house to look for wool.
It’s no use locking the stable door after the horse has bolted.
It’s not a matter of upper and lower class but of being up a while and down a while.
It’s not enough to know how to ride, you must also know how to fall.
It’s not the fault of the mouse, but of the one who offers him the cheese.
It’s not worth a cuckoo-spit.
It’s often a man’s mouth broke his nose.
It’s often a person’s mouth broke their nose.
Its outward display is greater than its value.
It’s sweet to drink but bitter to pay for it.
It’s the deaf people that create the lies.
It’s the last suitor that wins the maid.
It’s the quiet pigs that eat the grain.
It’s why women marry – the creatures, God bless them, are too shy to say no.
Keep a thing for seven years and you’ll find a use for it.
Keep a thing seven years and you’ll always find a use for it.
Keep the trickster on your side.
Knowledge comes through practice.
Lay up in time.
Laziness is a load. In Gaelic: Trom an rud an leisge.
Learning is no burden to a person.
Learning is the desire of the wise.
Let not your tongue cut your throat. (A fool’s tongue is long enough to cut his own throat.)
Lie down with dogs and you’ll rise with fleas.
Life is like a cup of tea,it’s all in how you make it.
Life is precious, as the tailor said when running from the gander.
Life’s too short not to be Irish!
Listen to the sound of the river and you will get a trout.
Little profit comes from constant drunkenness.
Long out of sight, far out of mind.
Look before you leap.
irish.description: Don’t rush into things! Make sure you know what is going to happen next. You would not jump off a cliff without first checking how far the ground is below or what there is to land on.

irish.text: Look before you speak. (Think before you speak.)
Lose an hour in the morning and you’ll be looking for it all day.
Love all men — except lawyers.
Love pursues profit. (I.e. Self-interest comes first, often love afterwards, in marriages for money.)
Make the fence or you will pay the plundering.
Man is incomplete until he marries. After that, he is finished.
Many a good parent had a bad child.
Many a thing happens that is never expected.
Many an Irish property was increased by the lace of a daughter’s petticoat.
Many quips a strong man will make
Marriages are all happy — it’s having breakfast together that causes all the trouble.
Marriages are all happy. It’s having breakfast together that causes all the trouble.
Marry a mountain girland you marry the whole mountain.
Marry in haste and repent at leisure.

May the road rise to meet you.May the wind be always at your back.May the sun shine warm upon your face.And rains fall soft upon your fields.And until we meet again,May God hold you in the hollow of His hand.
May the roof above us never fall in.And may the friends gathered below it never fall out.
May you get all your wishes but one, so that you will always have something to strive for!
May you have a bright future – as the chimney sweep said to his son.
May you live as long as you want and never want as long as you live.
May you live to be 100 years, with one extra year to repent.
May you live to be a hundred — and decide then rest for yourself.
May your joys be as deep as the valley. Your troubles as light as its foam. And may you find sweet peace of mind. Wherever you may roam.
Men are like bagpipes – no sound comes from them until they are full.
Men are like bagpipes, no sound comes from them until they are full.
Men are like bagpipes: no sound comes from them till they’re full.
Men may meet, but mountains never greet.
Mere words will not feed the friars.
Fair words butter no parsnips.
The belly is not filled with fair words.
Words will not feed the friars.
Mice won’t stay long in an empty house.
Might is two-thirds of right.
Money is like muck – no good till spread.
Mothers hold their children’s hands for just a little while…And their hearts forever.
Mr has a maid and yet Mr has to beg.
Much evil comes from talk that does not come from silence.
Musicians are craftsmen.
Musicians are brothers.
‘My belly thinks my throat is cut,’ as the hungry man said.
My little cottage, ever in disorder, one advantage you have – no matter how early or late I come, it is in you I can most easily stretch my legs. "Be it ever so humble, there is no place like home."
Nature shines through the cat’s eyes.
Never burn your fingers to snuff another man’s candle.
Never call a Kerry man a fool until you’re sure he’s not a rogue.
Never dread the winter till the snow is on the blanket.
irish.category: irish proverb(there’s no need to worry about the cold as long as you have a roof over your head.)

irish.text: Never give cherries to pigs or advice to a fool.
Never lie on the ground whilst a feather bed is beside you.
Never praise a ford till you go over.
Never scald your lips with another man’s porridge.
Nice teaching (= culture), the nicest thing in a person.
Ninety percent I’ll spend on good times, women and Irish Whiskey. The other ten percent I’ll probably waste.
No good is got by wasting, but a good name is got by alms-giving. (I.e. One ought not to waste, but -).
No man ever wore a cravat as nice, as his own child’s arm around his neck.
No man ever wore a scarf as warm as his daughter’s arm around his neck.
No man is wise at all times.
No man will another in the oven seek except that himself have been there before (Heywood).
No matter who dances, the piper will (= must) be paid.
No merriment in the seat of justice.
No one is ever poor who has the sight of his eyes and the use of his feet.
No time for health today, no health for your time tomorrow.
No time for your health today, no health for your time tomorrow.
Nobility listens to (or patronises) art.
Nobody ever bought peace but the man who hadn’t got it.
Nobody is wise till something goes against him.
Not every flatterer is a friend.
Nothing comes into a closed hand.
Nothing is preferable to reconciliation. (I.e. It is best to settle disputes amicably.)
Now sweetly lies old IrelandEmerald green beyond the foam,Awakening sweet memories,Calling the heart back home.
Often has a man cut a rod to beat himself.
Often has a ship been lost close to the harbour.
Often has a tattered colt grown to be a splendid horse. A ragged colt may make a good horse.
Often has the likely failed and the unlikely prospered.
One cannot draw blood from a turnip.
One good man is better than many worthless ones.
One look before is better than two behind.
One man’s meat is another man’s poison.
One may live without one’s friends but not without one’s pipe.
One swallow never made a summer.
One who is waiting thinks the time long.
Patience is poultice for all wounds.
People live in each other’s shelter.
Perseverance is the mother of good luck.
Pity him who makes an opinion a certainty.
Pity him who would burn his thiompán for you.’
Pity the man drowned in the storm; for after the rain comes the sunshine.
Pity the man who has a stranger’s spancel on him.
Pity the man who is drowned during the tempest, for after rain comes sunshine.
Pleasant on the outside, dark and gloomy on the inside.
Poor men take to the sea, rich to the mountain.
Postpone not a good action. In Gaelic: Ná cuir an mhaith ar cáirde.
Poverty destroys companionship.
Praise the child and you praise the mother.
Praise the young and they will blossom.
Prosperity comes to the lucky man without effort on his part, while he merely waits for it.
Prove a friend before poverty.
Provision for heaven – weighing and being strictly honest.
Put a beggar on horseback and he’ll ride to hell.
Put a coward to his metal an’ he’ll fight the de’il.
Put silk on a goat, and it’s still a goat.
Put the saddle on the right horse. (Blame the right person.)
Putting a withe around sand. Compare the English "a rope of sand."
The problem with Ireland is that it’s a country full of genius, but with absolutely no talent.
Putting one’s hand into an adder’s nest.
Questioning is the door of (i.e. the way to acquire) knowledge.
Questioning is the door of knowledge.
Riding on a goat is better than the very best walking.
Sailing against the wind.
Satire wounds a great character.
Say a little and say it well.
Scratch me and I’ll scratch you.
Seeing is believing, but feeling is the God’s own truth.
Seldom is there a slaughter from which no one escapes. Cf. English: ‘Tis a hard battle where none escapes.
Seldom is there champion who does not meet with some reverse.
Sending the goose on a message to the fox’s den.
Sense doesn’t come before age.
Sense is bettered by counsel. – A youth is the better for being instructed. – A wise man accepts advice. – It is bad not to take advice, but it is far worse to take every advice.
She is always in the field when luck is on the road (To be said of an unfortunate friend) .
She wipes the plate with the cat’s tail.
She’s fit to mind mice at a crossroads (To be said of someone who is unhelpful).
Show the fatted calf, but not the thing that fattened him.
Shun danger and it will shun you.
Shun evil company.
Shun the friendship of a lying man. Should you contract a friendship with him, be on your guard.
Slow is every foot on an unknown path.
Snuff at a wake is fine if there’s nobody sneezing over the snuffbox.
Snuff at a wake is fine if there’s nobody sneezing over the snuff box.
‘so near and yet so far,’ said the man when the bird lit on his gun.
Soft words butter no parsnips but they won’t harden the heart of a cabbage either.
Soft words butter no parsnips, but they won’t harden the heart of the cabbage either.
Sorrow will pay no debt.
Speak neither well nor ill of yourself.
Speak to the devil and you’ll hear the clatter of his hooves.
Speed and precision seldom agree. "Good and quickly seldom meet."
Spread your mantle only as you can draw it.
irish.category: irish proverb(i.e. do not attempt more than you are able for. var. cut your coat according to your cloth.)

irish.text: Still waters run deep.
irish.description: “Still waters run deep” describes people who are quiet and calm. These people often have “deep,” interesting personalities. So even if someone doesn’t talk a lot, they could still be very thoughtful.

irish.text: Story-telling [may become] a complicated affair.
Striking one’s head against a rock. Knocking one’s head against a stone wall.
Take stock of the river before you plunge into the current.
Take the world nice and easy, and the world will take you the same.
Talk does not fill the stomach.
Talk doesn’t fill the stomach.
Talk of the devil, and he will appear.
Tell it to Mary in a whisper, and Mary will tell it to the parish.
Tell me your company and I’ll tell you who you are.
That which is nearest a woman’s heart is the first to come out.
That’s a spoon ye’ll sup sorrow with yet.
The apple falls on the head that’s under it.
The bad deed turns on its doer.
The bark of a hound in a green glen.
The beginning and end of one’s life is to draw closer to the fire.
The best horse doesn’t always win the race.
The best way to keep loyalty in a man’s heart is to keep money in his purse.
The bird that can sing and won’t sing should be made to sing.
The bird that deserts its own brood has little affection.
The blacksmith’s horse and the cobbler’s wife are always the last to have shoes.
The borrowed horse has hard hoofs.
The calf belongs to the owner of the cow.
The cat has leave to look at the king.
The cat is his own best adviser.
The clothes are (= make) the man (i.e. his outward appearance).
The clown searches for the mare and he sitting on her.
The cow is milked from her head.
It is from her head the cow is milked. (First feed her, that is.)
The dog that’s always on the go, is better than the one that’s always curled up.
The eating of it is the proof of the pudding.
The proof of the pudding is in the eating of it.
The proof of the pudding lies in the eating of it.
The end of feast is better than the beginning of a quarrel.
The English always credit the rest of us with the qualities they don’t need themselves.
The expectation of recouping himself is what beggars the gambler.
The hope of winning proves the gambler’s undoing.
The fox never found a surer messenger than himself.
The friend is proved when the need is greatest.
The friend that can be bought is not worth buying.
The future is not set, there is no fate but what we make for ourselves.
The greater the strait the more valuable is the help.
The heaviest ear of corn is the one that lowliest hangs its head.
irish.category: irish proverb(this expresses the humility of the truly great, and it implies that the grandest characters are not always to be found among those of most elevated rank.)

irish.text: The heaviest ear of grain bends its head the lowest.
The herb that can’t be got is the one that heals.
The historian’s food is truth.
The Irishman is an impatient fellow.
The lake is not encumbered by the swan, and the body is not encumbered by good sense.
The last place is meet for the best beloved.
The law of borrowing is to break the borrower.
The losing horse blames the saddle.
The lucky man waits for prosperity.
irish.category: irish proverb(i.e. prosperity comes to him without effort on his part.)

irish.text: The magic of Christmas lingers onThough childhood days have passedUpon the common round of lifeA Holy Spell is cast
The man at sea may return but not the man in the churchyard.
The man of the boots doesn’t care where he puts his foot.
The man who has luck in the morning has luck in the afternoon.
The man who was dividing Ireland didn’t leave himself last.
The miller’s pigs are fat but God knows whose meal they ate.
The miller’s pigs are fat but it wasn’t all mouter they ate.
The mills of God grind slowly but they grind finely.
The mother would never seek her daughter in the oven had not herself been there first (Clarke).
The mountain is a good mustard.
irish.category: irish proverb(i.e. work or exercise on the mountain is a good appetiser.)

irish.text: The mouth that speaks not is sweet to hear.
The new broom sweeps the house best.
The old boot gets the old stocking. (Said when an old couple marries.)
The old person is a child twice.
The old woman is the better of being warmed, but she is the worse of being burned.
The older the fiddle the sweeter the tune.
The ox’s part in milking-time. (I.e. the role of an idle spectator.)
The person who doesn’t scatter the morning dew will not comb gray hairs.
The person who is rich is none the worse for being dull in accomplishments and in understanding, for being stammering in speech, or for having but one foot or one hand.
The pig in the sty doesn’t know the pig going along the road.
The pleasantry of children is nice.
The priest’s pig gets the most porridge.
The reason the Irish are always fighting each other is they have no other worthy opponents.
The shoemaker’s wife and the blacksmith’s horse often go unshod.
The sweat of one’s brow is what burns everyone.
The thing that often occurs is not much appreciated.
The three sharpest things in the world: a thorn in the mud, a hemp rope, a fool’s word.
The tiredness leaves but the profit remains.
The treachery returns to the betrayer.
The value of the well is not understood till it goes dry.
The wearer best knows where the shoe pinches him.
The well fed person doesn’t understand the hungry one.
The windy day is not the day for thatching.
The wisdom of the Englishman and the openness of the Gael – that is what does the harm.
The world goes round as if there were wings on it.
The world would not make a racehorse of a donkey
The world’s quiet and the pig is in the sty.
There are only two kinds of people in the world, the Irish and those who wish they were.
There are three creatures beyond ruling – a mule, a pig and a woman.
There are three kinds of men, — the worker, the pleasure-seeker, and the boaster.
irish.category: irish proverb(allow for combinations, such as ‘the pleasure-seeking worker’, "the boasting pleasure-seeker (flaunter)", and other types as well.)

irish.text: There is an Irish way of paying compliments as though they were irresistible truths which makes what would otherwise be an impertinence delightful.
There is hope from the sea, but none from the grave.
There is luck in leisure.
There is luck in sharing thing.
There is many a person with a high head today who shall be lying lowly tomorrow.
There is many a thing you hear that is not right to put in print.
There is no fireside like your own fireside.
There is no ghost as bad as the ghost with two legs.
There is no such thing as bad publicity except your own obituary.
There is no tax on talk.
There is no tune without a penny.
There is no wise man without fault.
There is nothing sharper than a woman’s tongue.
There is often a barb behind a kiss.
There is often anger in a laugh.
There is often the look of an angel on the Devil himself.
There is only one thing worse than being talked about, and that is not being talked about.
There is only the blackberry got from the briar.
There is skill in all things even in making porridge.
There never was a scabby sheep in a flock that didn’t like to have a comrade.
There tends to be a black sheep in even the whitest flock.
There was never a scabby sheep in a flock that didn’t like to have a comrade.
There’s no need to fear the wind if your haystacks are tied down.
There’ll be white blackbirds before an unwilling woman ties the knot.
There’s a fool born every minute – and every one of them lives.
There’s as many good horses in carts as in coaches.
There’s little to choose between two blind goats.
There’s little value in the single cow.
There’s many a good tune played on an old fiddle.
There’s many a ship lost within sight of harbour.
There’s neither success nor efficiency without authority and laws.
There’s never a wise man without fault.
There’s no hearth like your own hearth.
There’s no hearthstone like your own hearthstone.
There’s no sore ass like your own sore ass.
There’s no wise man without a fault.
There’s no worth to a story without an author.
There’s trouble in every house and some in he street.
Think before you speak, and look before you leap.
irish.description: Don’t rush into things! Make sure you know what is going to happen next. You would not jump off a cliff without first checking how far the ground is below or what there is to land on.

irish.text: Thirst is a shameless disease. (The thirst for intoxicants is meant.)
This world is the world of everyone in turn.
Those who make laws should not break laws.
Those who make the best preparation for a work [can] make the greatest progress.
Thou oughtest to increase good.
Though wisdom is good in the beginning, it is better at the end.
Though your fame is great, it is not good.
Three best to have in plenty – sunshine, wisdom and generosity.
Three diseases without shame: Love, itch and thirst.
Three things that can’t be taught: generosity, poetry and a singing voice.
‘Tis afterwards that everything is understood.
‘Tis as hard to see a woman cry, as a goose go barefoot.
‘Tis better to buy a small bouquetAnd give to your friend this very day,Than a bushel of roses white and redTo lay on his coffin after he’s dead.
‘Tis better to spend money like there’s no tomorrow than to spend tonight like there’s no money!
To someone who committed some small fault – ‘Tis only a stepmother would blame you.’
To think of it is as good as to mention it.
irish.category: irish proverb(i.e., better think of it without saying anything about it.)

irish.text: Too much familiarity breeds contempt.
Truth has but one version.
Twenty years a child; twenty years running wild; twenty years a mature man — and after that, praying.
Twenty years a child;twenty years running wild;twenty years a mature man,and after that, praying.
Two good things: a young man courting, an old man smoking. Two bad things: an old man courting, a young man smoking.
Two people see a thing that an individual does not see.
Walk straight, my son – as the old crab said to the young crab.
We’ll never know the worth of water till the well go dry.
‘what a dust we kick up,’ as the fly said to the cart wheel.
What appears full of promise often turns out a failure.
What butter and whiskey will not cure there’s no cure for.
What butter and whiskey will not cure, there’s no cure for.
What butter and whiskey won’t cure, there is no cure for.
What butter or whiskey will not cure, there is no cure for.
irish.category: irish proverb(absurd belief in the great medicinal efficacy of whiskey has wrought untold harm, says the author of seanfhocla uladh)

irish.text: What I’m afraid to hear I’d better say first myself.
What is fated for me it is hard to shun.
What is in the cat is in the kitten.
What should prevent the herring bag from having the odour of the herrings?
What the child sees (done) is what the child does.
What won’t choke will fatten and clean dirt is no poison.
Whatever knowledge, education, or learning the clown acquires, his own congenial nature still appears.
What’s all the world to a man when his wife is a widow.
What’s good for the goose is good for the gander.
What’s got badly, goes badly.
What’s in the marrow is hard to take out of the bone.
When all things spoke the potato said, ‘set me warm, dig me warm, eat me warm, that’s all i want.’
When everybody’s house is on fire go home and look at your own chimney.
When luck comes, it comes by the bucketful.
When the apple is ripe it will fall.
When the belly is full, the bones like to stretch.
When the cat is out the mice will dance.
When the cat is out, the mice dance.
When the cat is outside, the mouse does be dancing.
When the cats leave the town (or home), the mice dance.
irish.category: irish proverb(when superiors are gone the subordinates make merry.)

irish.text: When the drop (drink) is inside, the sense is outside.
When the fire is lighted it is hard to put it out.
When the old cock crows the young one learns.
When the old hag is in danger she must run.
When the river sounds, it’s because it carries water.
When the seed stops, the harrowing stops.
When the sky falls we’ll all catch larks.
When the sky falls we’ll catch larks.
When the sky falls, we’ll all catch larks.
When the stomach is full, rest is pleasant. When the stomach is full, the bones crave rest.
When the twig has become an old tree is not the time to bend it.
When the two ends of the candle are lighted it does not stand long.
When your hand is in the dog’s mouth, withdraw it gently.
When your neighbour’s house is on fire, take care of your own.
When you’re not fishing be mending the nets.
Where there is smoke there is fire.
irish.category: irish proverb(where there is much evidence of a thing, the thing itself is likely to exist.)

irish.text: Wherever there are women there’s talking, and wherever there’s geese there’s cackling.
Wherever you go and whatever you do, may the luck of the Irish be there with you.
While a person is out, his food goes cold (nothing does well, if neglected).
While young, it’s all dreams; when old, all memories.
Whiskey when you’re sick makes you well; whiskey makes you sick when you’re well.
Who gossips with you will gossip of you.
Who keeps his tongue keeps his friends.
Whoever the cap fits takes it. • Let him whom the cap suits wear it.
Wine pours out the truth.
Winter comes on the lazy man.
Wisdom exceeds riches.
Wisdom exceeds strength.
Wisdom is the comb given to a man after he has lost his hair.
Without education, without manners.
irish.category: irish proverb(he who is without sound education, is also without good manners etc.)

irish.text: Without pressing him either too little or too much, keep a sure grip on the reins, for he is a fool who would not get value out of the horse he has on loan.
Without pressing too little or too hard, hold tight the reins for he’s a fool who would not get value from a borrowed horse.
Without treasure, without friends.
Woe to her whose husband is a surly fool.
Woe to him who burns his old cattle fold and has thus no reserve to fall back on if the new cattle fold should fail him. (i.e. One should not burn one’s boats.)
Woe to him who burns his old hnaile (cattlefold).
irish.category: irish proverb(and has thus no reserve to fall back on if the new huaile should fail him. i.e. one should not burn one’s boats.)

irish.text: Woe to him who deems his opinion a certainty.
Woe to him who fails in his obligations. • He is a sorry wretch who fails to keep his bonds.
Woe to him who has a wretched house, but doubly woeful is he who has no house at all.
Woe to him who is without a wife, but doubly woeful is he who has one.
Woe to him who lets his secret (known) to a fence. • Never reveal your secret to a fence or a hedge.
Woe to him whose betrayer sits at his table.
Woe to him whose liberty depends on a stranger.
Ye didn’t turn up when sense being distributed.
Ye pleasant men, are ye aware of the nature of children? What we have is theirs, but what they get is not ours.
You can take a man out of the bog, but you can’t take the bog out of the man.
You can’t kiss an Irish girl unexpectedly. You can only kiss her sooner than she thought you would.
You cannot eat your bread and have it.
You cannot make a silk purse out of a sow’s ear.
You cannot tell from a man’s clothes how much he is making, but you must look at his wife’s.
You can’t build a barrel around a bung hole.
You can’t build a barrel round a bung hole.
You can’t make a silk purse out of a sow’s ear.
You can’t put a wide head on young shoulders.
You can’t teach an old dog new tricks.
You can’t whistle and drink at the same time.
You couldn’t make half a football team out of all the Leinster men in Heaven.
You didn’t turn up when sense was being distributed.
You might as well be whistling jigs to a milestone.
irish.category: irish proverb(when a friend can’t change a stubborn person’s mind).

irish.text: You must take the little potato with the big potato.
You never had neighbours as good as boundary fences.
You will not be able to make a silk purse of a pig’s ear.
irish.category: irish proverb(you’ll not be able to make a person naturally boorish and vulgar to be refined and decent.)

irish.text: You won’t learn to swim on the kitchen floor.
You’ll never plow a field by turning it over in your mind.
You’ve got to do your own growing, no matter how tall your father was.
You’ll never plough a field by turning it over in your mind.
You’ll not find a thrush in a hawk’s nest.
Young people, make the web of life well.
Your feet will bring you to where your heart is.
Your feet will bring you where your heart is.
Your friend and your enemy think you will never die.
Your lord’s rent or your child’s life.
Your own business, do it, my man.
Your son is your son today, but your daughter is your daughter forever.
You’re not as young as you used to be, but you’re not as old as you’re going to be.
Youth sheds many a skin. The steed (horse) does not retain its speed forever.
You’ve got to do your own growing, no matter how tall your grandfather was.
Firelight will not let you read fine stories but it’s warm and you won’t see the dust on the floor.
Every disease is a physician.
If the knitter is weary the baby will have no new bonnet.
What’s got badly goes badly.
A silent mouth is sweet to hear
Drink is the curse of the land. It makes you fight with your neighbor. It makes you shoot at your landlord and it makes you miss him.
Every beginning is weak.
Any man can lose his hat in a fairy wind.
May the holes in your net be no larger than the fish in it.
You have not built a wall unless you have rounded a corner.
Twenty years a child; twenty years running wild; twenty years a mature man –and after that, praying.
The person who doesn’t scatter the morning dew will not comb grey hairs.
May you have a bright future — as the chimney sweep said to his son.
You are not a fully fledged sailor unless you have sailed under full sail.
Walk straight, my son — as the old crab said to the young crab.
Good luck comes in slender currents, misfortune in a rolling tide.
You’ve got to do your own growing, not matter how tall your grandfather was.
A a good run is better than a bad fight.
May you always have walls for the winds, a roof for the rain, tea beside the fire, laughter to cheer you, those you love near you and all your heart might desire.
When the drop is inside the sense is outside.
In the New Year, may your right hand always be stretched out in friendship, but never in want.
A son is a son till he takes him a wife, a daughter is a daughter all of her life.
A new broom sweeps clean, but the old broom knows the corners.
Smoke your pipe and be silent; there’s only wind and smoke in the world.
In heaven there is no beer, that’s why we drink ours here.
Women do not drink liquor but it disappears when they are present.
Man’s way to God is with beer in hand.
Though honey is sweet, don’t lick it off a briar.
Marriages are all happy. It’s having breakfast together that causes all the trouble.
A quarrel is like buttermilk: once it’s out of the churn, the more you shake it, the more sour it grows.
Better be quarrelling than lonesome.
There is hope from the sea, but none from the grave.
Do not mistake a goat’s beard for a fine stallion’s tail.
The best beer is where priests go to drink.
Do not mistake a goat’s beard for a fine stallion’s tail.
A dog does not flee from a bone.
If you hit my dog you hit myself.
When a twig grows hard it is difficult to twist it.

Ireland is an island in the North Atlantic. It is separated from Great Britain to its east by the North Channel, the Irish Sea, and St George’s Channel. Ireland is the second-largest island of the British Isles, the third-largest in Europe, and the twentieth-largest on Earth.

Politically, Ireland is divided between the Republic of Ireland (officially named Ireland), which covers five-sixths of the island, and Northern Ireland, which is part of the United Kingdom, in the northeast of the island. In 2011, the population of Ireland was about 6.4 million, ranking it the second-most populous island in Europe after Great Britain. Just under 4.6 million live in the Republic of Ireland and just over 1.8 million live in Northern Ireland.
Ireland is a sovereign state in north-western Europe occupying about five-sixths of the island of Ireland. The capital and largest city is Dublin, which is located on the eastern part of the island.

The Irish language, also referred to as Gaelic or Irish Gaelic, is a Goidelic language of the Indo-European language family originating in Ireland and historically spoken by the Irish people. (An excerpt from Wikipedia)
As the old cock crows the young cock learns.
There is no woman more accustomed to bad shoes on her than the cobbler’s wife.
Walls have ears.
Neither give cherries to pigs nor advice to fools.
The apple does not fall far from the tree.
Don’t change your horse when you are about to cross a river.
Turning it over in your mind won’t plough the field.
Better one good thing that is than two good things that were.
Youth sheds many a skin.
If you want to know me come and live with me.
Things aren’t as they seem.
Sense does not come before age.
A rolling stone gathers no moss.
irish.description: To be successful in life you need to settle down in one place and stop moving all the time. It also means that an active busy person will never stagnate and should prove to be productive and creative.

irish.text: In at one ear and out at the other.
There was often a bad cloth on a tailor and a bad shoe on a cobbler.
A scholar’s ink lasts longer than a martyr’s blood.
Money swore an oath that nobody who did not love it should ever have it.
It’s not a matter of upper and lower class but of being up awhile and down awhile.
Love is blind to blemishes and fault.
irish.description: If you love someone, you don’t notice his or her faults. You think they’re perfect.

irish.text: You must live with a person to know a person.
The people meet each other but the hills do not.
The trick the father has, the son has.
The little fish feed the big fish.
Three things that are never visible: the tip of the blade, wind, and love.
The heart of loved ones is your strength
The one who kisses in public often makes you cry in private.
Open your eyes wide before marriage, close your eyes after marriage.
Love should be shared with your wife and secrets with mother.
Love at first sight often comes at dusk.
The kiss is as pleasant as delicious food, but it lasts shorter.
If whiskey cannot cure love – this love is hopeless!
